title: What will be the closing price per barrel for West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil on 22 September 2020, according to Bloomberg?
preds: Oil closed at $39.70, would take a 12% single day change to move outside of the bucket, and I think this is highly unlikely.
Damn, (small) chance it might go under $35. Will monitor.

Energy is crashing alongside most other markets today (Natural Gas -10%, Heating Oil -3.5%, Silver -8.3%, Platinum -6.1%, Gold -3.2%, not to mention stocks), it seems a lot of the hot air expectations that has kept the markets rising for the last two months is now leaking. I hope the 35 to 45 USD is not in danger, at least not by tomorrow closing (currently 39.30USD at -4.2%).
Barring no major news, I feel comfortable moving to 100% given we are only one day from settlement.
Updating given Friday close 41.11$ + now it is almost in the middle of the 35$-45$ so feel even more confident here
Updating as current price is right in the middle of the 35-45 bucket - and a 5 dollar move in oil, in either direction, over the span of two days would be quite a large move.
Dropping as very little time remains.
Updating with passage of time, current price being at $41.02

Decreasing the size of my tails as it is now at 41.23$, in the 35-45 bucket since 1m+ and the uncertainty has decreased. Oil futures are again up today after Saudi Arabia's energy minister took a stern tone on compliance with OPEC+ production curbs and dared speculators to short crude. Prices are up for their largest weekly gain since June. The small drop following the annoucement of potential libyan exports is completely pared now.
Updated for the WTI market price on Friday.
Updated given recent price moves as well as OPEC and Saudi Arabia
Most of oil catalysts are out of the way, even though OPEC is planning supply cuts and reforms, these will likely not hit by September 22.

Expectations of supply disruptions from the offshore industry in the Gulf of Mexico during the ongoing Hurricane season, besides lowered inventory, may propel the WTI spot prices to more than 45USD/bbl. It is unlikely, however, to happen until 22 Sep 2020 close, which means a 7% total gain or more than 2.3% daily return on average for the next 3 days, including today. Historically, such short term rallies are not uncommon, so today's trading imho decides, whether this will still be possible.

Back up to $41.25.
If it didn’t drop below $35 after last week’s demand concerns, it’s not going to do it in the next 5 days.

Oil has broken above 40 dollars and sits in the middle of the range now. Dropping probabilities in two tail outcomes given we are within a week of settlement. Pre mortem: Geopolitical shock, strong OPEC actions, etc.

Updating with passage of time. Oil now at ~$40 with 4 trading days to go, news on US oil inventories being lower has already taken effect, and OPEC monthly production report was already released on Monday. Thus, make distribution more tight around the mean.
As of this moment, price is $40.13.
Updating based on updated option deltas. Seems as though there is consensus that the price should fall between 35 and 45.

As raised by @hermannviktor (thanks for this) oil extended gains to near $39 a barrel in New York, buoyed by an industry report of a surprise drop in U.S. crude stockpiles. The American Petroleum Institute (API) reported on Tuesday a draw in crude oil inventories of 9.517 million barrels for the week ending September 11. Analysts had predicted an inventory draw of 1.271-million barrels. + The UAE sent a fresh signal it will make up for pumping too much oil in the past two months. https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Oil-Rises-On-Major-Crude-Draw.html

U.S. crude inventories sank by 9.52 million barrels last week, the API is said to have reported. That would be the biggest draw since July and drag supplies back to the lowest since early April if confirmed by the EIA --> report comes out at 10.30am ET
Oil continues to trade range bound.
Updating to current prices and tightening dist slightly
Updated initial conditions and slightly changed volatility based on recent historical changes.
If more platforms and refiners are shut as a result of hurricanes, will that tend to spike the WTI price?
8 days to expiry, oil remaining in 35-45 bucket
Shift weight based on time passing. I leave mass for the tails in case of some tail event.
Estimating the likely prices based on the deltas of options on CL1.

Rerunning my monte carlo simulations taking into account last week values and few days remaining I obtain the results above. I was first tented to increase the 35-45 bucket but I do feel a lot of uncertainty remains:
-   OPEC downgraded its outlook for the global oil market [1] a few days before ministers meet, amid faltering demand and signs of a recovery in supply from U.S. shale drillers. More precisely Group cuts 2021 demand estimate for its oil by 1.1 million b/d. 
- Today s price drops below 40$ close to the lowest in 2 months   -> I will watch closely the meeting of the Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee scheduled for Thursday. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/14/oil-and-coronavius-opec-cuts-2020-demand-forecast-trims-2021-outlook.html

used historical daily return mean and variance to simulate draws from a random dist. used last two years' data, last year, and last 45 days. My estimate is an average of these three with more weight given to last 45 days.
Updated based on recent market conditions.
Updating to reflect latest options deltas.

They are trying to secure tankers for storage...sign of too much oil sloshing around in market. Would like to think will stay above 35 (currently $37) in this timeframe but has moved quicker than thought. Not covered well that I saw, Saudi cut rates for Asia and North America.
9/11 close=37.49USD/bbl. up .5% on the day. Perhaps we've found a short term sweet spot.

Ironically the reduced oil price has OPEC reconsidering price cuts to make up difference with (greater) supply. Prices are going to get interesting (lower). Tough call if we’ll hit $35 in 11 days, however,
Updating with new prices and extremeizing based on my team forecast.

9/9 close = 37.33USD/bbl. relatively flat from the previous day. 
Oil is under pressure due to reduced demand and over supply.
Updating with new data, WTI CL1 is currently trading at $37.67, lowest since ~june levels

I ran a monte carlo simulation using the data from the futures prices for the last 30 days. Mean and standard deviation derived from the data pulled from bloomberg to derive the underlying distribution for price settlement 12 days out.

Price collapse in response to reports showing increased inventory, as I mentioned in my previous update as a possibility. Overall economic picture remains mixed, especially with covid impact differing among countries.
Used options prices to generate probability distributions for oil prices. Current price is 37,40. Market falls are significantly more volatile than upwards movement.
Updating with options prices following today's move. Also keeping in mind prices are down after hours.

A bump in the road. But still leaning toward the 35 to 45 bucket.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-08/oil-extends-biggest-drop-in-3-months-as-demand-worries-escalate?utm_source=url_link

I used the ratio of the dime to dollar to set these probabilities, seemed like the best model to me at the time.
No other model works any better.
Updating to todays moves and using options to infer prob dist

Similiar to the approach taken by @pchi , we look at the CLV0 futures contract, the WTI Crute Oct 20 futures which stop trading on Sept 22. The current price of this contract is 36.66. Next, using options on this contract we determine the probability distribution for the above thresholds using the option's delta.

As mentioned on my first forecast I will adapt my forecast given the move of the $.  The dollar and Treasuries gained today + on the outlook of worsening demand for oil, contango for both Brent and WTI widened. This is a sign of oversupply. -> i move my distribution slightly to the left

We are increasing the probability of a down move given two main macroeconomic events: (1) recovery outlooks look worse to what people expected (lots of macroeconomic data came out today) and (2) OPEC is thinking about increasing production. (1) decreases demand, (2) increases supply, both of which lead to a lower price.

Used volatility from options to approximate potential distribution of prices. Noted that a lot of the skew was to the downside, ie the market expects that downward shocks will be more volatile than upwards ones

Covid news has settled down and barring any major surprises markets have priced in the possibility of recurring outbreaks. WTI vols have dropped enormously since march with opec unlikely to provoke another slide in oil prices. I believe risk is skewed towards upside surprises right now.
Generated a random walk using changes in price over the last two months.
Based on team & crowd consensus and slightly extremized

Probabilities generated from options on CLV0 with 9/22 expiry, as well as taking into account a recent negative sentiment on oil based on general market concerns and wavering demand. Though oil has remained in the 35-45 bucket for the last three months, falling below 35 would be possible if additional OPEC/COVID news comes out signalling even less demand.  https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Oil-Prices-Fall-Below-40-On-Demand-Concerns.html
Taking account of most recent data

WTI has been above $25 since mid-May and above $35 since the beginning of June, and seems to have found an equilibrium between the $40 and $45 level. A recovering economy and the likely accompanying demand makes upward pressure more likely than downward pressure.

Using options prices for the CLV20 contract (with Sept 17 expiry), we can use the deltas of those options contracts to get a rough approximation of the buckets for 9/22. If we think of  10DP: strike = 34.69
15DP: 36.04
25DP: 37.62
35DP: 38.67
50D: 39.88
35DC: 40.98
25DC: 41.79
15DC: 42.83
10DC: 43.60 The 15DP for the nov contract has a strike of 34.10, and the 15DC has a strike of 45.71 to give us some additional perspective. This gives us the approximate distribution above, but will update again when markets are open.

Would need to move 10% up or down to move out of 35-45 range. Looked at historical numbers and such moves in 2 weeks do happen but aren’t common. Limited upward pressure (conflict or sharp economic moves). Some downward pressure, but again limited.

I conducted a monte carlo simulation for the next 12 days of price movements. In order to decide on the base volatility I looked at historical 30 and 50 day volatility on bloomberg. I also looked at options on CL1 futures however the next expiration is not until late october so this isnt too instructive. I made a slight upward adjustment as option ivol is quite a bit higher than the realized vol. Next I looked at potential vol events/trends in the oil markets. The run up to the us election is a possible reason to increase vol as remarks on US relations with other OPEC members may cause prices to shift. As @hermannviktor pointed out there is an OPEC releae on sep14 however historically these events have not caused an increase in vol. Lastly I factored in @cls remarks on the contago of markets and added a minor downward shift in the returns distribution. https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/338.html
https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/090320-us-elections-trump-biden-race-holds-big-oil-policy-impacts-for-shale-sanctions

As many folks have pointed out, WTI has traded range-bound for several weeks now and it is not clear that it will break out. As my colleague @hermannviktor points out, the major macroeconomic event that could affect oil prices is the OPEC publication on 9/14, albeit all states are relatively following the set guidelines. All other macroeconomic numbers are in my opinion, "noise"; for example, certainly US sector job growth has been steadily recovering since April but oil has ceased to really break out above 50 as a result. On the other hand @cls has simulated out the future price using Monte Carlo simulation with BM. As such, I split my weight between the historical analysis vs. the simulated future analysis with BM. I will track the OPEC report to see how it pans out as well as following Cushing, OK numbers to see oil buildup/drawdown.

Base rate: I followed the same process than for the TSLA and SPX questions and modeled the WTI Crude Oil future by a geometric Brownian motion. Running 100000 Monte Carlo simulations gave me the following results:
-	Less than $25.00 0%
-	Between $25.00 and $35.00, inclusive 10%
-	More than $35.00 but less than $45.00 81% -> looks reasonable given that . WTI traded in the range of $34-$44 for the last 3 months.
-	Between $45.00 and $55.00, inclusive 9%
-	More than $55.00 0%
Adjustment
-	The $40 level has been violated on Friday Sept 4 as the coronavirus continues to rage in many parts of the world and the demand outlook remains uncertain. Purchases by China, the world’s largest importer, are likely to slow as smaller refineries top out their shipment quotas. The US gasoline demand last week fell to 8.78 million barrels per day (bpd) from 9.16 million bpd a week earlier. If this downward momentum continues, the market is likely to go towards the $35 level. The market’s struThe market’s structure has also weakened in recent days. WTI’s near-term contracts are at their biggest discount to later ones since June, a structure known as contango that indicates growing concerns about oversupply. That is why I adjusted the basis rate to the left tail. 
-	That being said: OPEC+, are currently cutting output by 7.7 million barrels per day (bpd) until December to support prices. There is no sign of major short term change in this politic, apart from Iraq that indicated it won’t be able to reduce production as quickly as previously promised. 
-	In the next days, I will also closely monitor the US dollar. https://www.arabnews.com/node/1730156/business-economy
https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Iraq-Looks-To-Be-Exempted-From-OPEC-Cuts-In-Q1-2021.html

Bloomberg 9/5 "Saudi Arabia cut pricing for oil sales to Asia and the U.S. for October shipments, a sign that the world’s biggest exporter may see fuel demand wavering amid flare-ups in the coronavirus."

Baseline: We looked at the historical WTI futures price development, however there are very few datapoints that correctly represent the market environment and market sentiment. We analyzed rolling averages and observe that prices have been in the 35-45 bound since June (and closed at $39.77 on Friday). OPEC considerations:
Oil price is mainly driven by OPEC decisions regarding their production limits. Therefore, when predicting WTI price, it is crucial to analyze how OPEC might act in the future. For this time period, we know that OPEC will have 1 more monthly publication, on September 14. To understand the dynamics there, one needs to see how each member is doing on their production limits set by OPEC. Recent news suggest that most members are in line with the discussed production limits, however, Iraq appears to be having problems implementing the additional production cuts (7.7M barrels / day) agreed on in the last OPEC meeting (see https://blinks.bloomberg.com/news/stories/QG5B3SBP8R2B). However, one needs to not that the last 3 meetings had no strong bearing on the price of crude oil. Other macroeconomic factors:
Asia:
There is a discussion about the weaker demand from Asia, especially from China, following reports that suggested what the market had anticipated all along -- Saudi Arabia will probably cut prices for October shipments by about a $1 per barrel.
US:
Private-sector US job growth in August was the slowest since the recovery began in May (August nonfarm payrolls -- 1.37M versus Bloomberg compiled consensus for 1.35M).
Europe:
Germany reported new manufacturing orders increased in July at 2.8% compared with an almost 29% surge in June as a drop in the domestic market undermined the jump seen overseas, signaling a moderate recovery from the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Construction activity fell in the eurozone, with the IHS Markit construction PMI declining to 47.8 in August versus 48.9 in July. Conclusion: There are no current catalysts expected until September 22, therefore we put the main part of our distribution into the historical values, however, we also accept that there is some negative sentiment in the market that might push price further down. At the same time, we can also not discard the possibility that some Coronavirus number lets the value go out of our upper bound, even though this has not happened since the start of the pandemic, indicating that there needs to be substantial news to drive the price above that value.

A lot of economies performing at various velocities so it's hard to capture that. There's evidence of increased storage in response to the output increase last month which likely will keep prices below $55, but spikes happen. We're still hovering around the cutoff, so we could easily end up at $45+ just due to short-term variance.
Stock market crash is possible. Even with some volatility, it should stay around $40 for the month of September.
Sept 4 = 39.77USD/bbl. down 4% on the day. Yikes is someone pumping more or are we driving less?

Currently (9/4) trading at $39.90, and has traded in 35-45 band since June.
Starting with production, OPEC has cut production since March, but August production was actually ~2% higher than July, which would imply a slight decrease in price.
However, I think consumption is likely rebounding since April lows (when many countries were shut down), although probably not by a massive amount. Thus, I believe it likely offsets the production increase since June, and may actually push price slightly higher in aggregate.
I also looked at seasonality, but since the futures contract will not roll until 9/22 this is not a factor. Because of the above, I came up with a distribution that's heavily concentrated at the mean. I think it's possible the contract drops below the $35 band (likely would be due to COVID-related issues), but it may also increase past the $45 if demand rebounds more than anticipated. Since I think the former is more likely, I slightly skewed distribution towards the lower side.

Current prices have trended up steadily since June. I think it's unlikely we see another drop below 35 in absence of a lockdown. Even with the trend, I think its much more likely that we finish in the lower bucket 35-45.

jeremy and I looked at the contract price on https://oilprice.com/oil-price-charts/
Since May the price has very steadily hovered between 35-45, and currently is dead center of the range. I believe there is minimal likelihood (<5%) of another price drop, whereas the small chance of a vaccine makes it possible (10%) for a price spike in airline needs.
Current consensus overweighting one bucket by a lot.
WTI barely moved during the big move today. 35 pu does have 4 delta, but u can't trust the skew lol.

Sept 3 midday =40.73USD/bbl. down 2%. If we are all driving Teslas, will oil be worth so much? With activity haltingly returning, this should not move the needle over the next 3 weeks. Nickel, copper and cobalt the new oil?
In the last 30 days WTI has gone from $41 -> $43 as people resume driving and some flying. In the next 21 days will it rise another $2? Sept 1 = 43.14USD/bbl. up slightly.

After playing with my latest toy (the Hurst exponent and the fractal geometry of stock markets), I have been re-considering this question: 1) H is in between 0.80 (last 64 days) and 0.87 (last 256 days), which indicates a trend.
2) Outside-viewing and doing the bins I obtain something like {0,0,80,20,0}
3) This looks a bit too sharp, so I smeared the probabilities a bit too {0,0,67,33,0}, though this is a matter of taste.
4) Other approaches (e.g a simple linear fit of recent prices) lead to similar probabilities.

WTI has been really quiet since July, having a realized volatility of just 21%. The Crude Oil Volatility Index OVX has fallen from over 500% in April to just 32%, undoing Covid-19. Therefore, this question doesn't have a lot of juice in it unless something dramatic happens (stock market crash, supply disruption). Currently, the crowd pays more for the $45 call than options traders on the NYMEX, so I am contributing their crowd wisdom here and hope for a quiet 3 weeks.. https://www.tradingview.com/chart/?symbol=NYMEX%3ACL2!
Correction of previous mistake, I was thinking brent
Unless you're naughty, life begins at forty   :) Would think it is either going to be stable in the mid forties or would go up
The oil is trending up over last few months. In addition this is the hurricane season. Any hit to oil rings in Gulf of Mexico can easily move the oil prices above $45
